channel.title: Network on TLDRBins
channel.description: Recent content in Network on TLDRBins

item.title: Firewall (Windows)
item.description: Windows Check Firewall Rules # cmd cmd /c "netsh advfirewall firewall show rule name=all|findstr Name:" # powershell Get-NetFirewallProfile # Check outbound rules Get-NetFirewallRule -Direction Outbound -Enabled True # Pretty print powershell -c "Get-NetFirewallRule -Direction Outbound -Enabled True -Action Block | Format-Table -Property DisplayName,@{Name='Protocol';Expression={($PSItem | Get-NetFirewallPortFilter).Protocol}},@{Name='LocalPort';Expression={($PSItem | Get-NetFirewallPortFilter).LocalPort}},@{Name='RemotePort';Expression={($PSItem | Get-NetFirewallPortFilter).RemotePort}},@{Name='RemoteAddress';Expression={($PSItem | Get-NetFirewallAddressFilter).RemoteAddress}}, Enabled, Profile,Direction,Action" Add Inbound Rules # Allow all inbound traffic from local subnet New-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "Allow All" -Direction Inbound -Enabled True -RemoteAddress LocalSubnet -Action Allow -Protocol TCP -Profile ANY

item.title: Network Discovery
item.description: Test connectivity Linux Windows # Default infinite pings ping -c3 <TARGET> # Default 5 pings ping <TARGET> # Check specific port Test-NetConnection <TARGET> -Port <TARGET_PORT> Test reverse connectivity Linux sudo tcpdump -ni tun0 icmp Sniff network traffic Linux # For example: on port 389 sudo tcpdump -i lo -nnXs 0 'port <TARGET_PORT>' # Sniff HTTPS traffic sudo ./mitmdump -p 443 --mode reverse:https://<DOMAIN> --ssl-insecure --set flow_detail=3 Ref: mitmproxy Use ping to scan subnet Linux for i in $(seq 1 254); do (ping -c 1 10.

item.title: Network Traffic Pivoting
item.description: Tunneling Chisel ssh socat metasploit sliver Start a local chisel Server # In our local Linux machine ./chisel server --reverse --port <LOCAL_PORT> Ports forwarding # In target machine ./chisel client <LOCAL_IP>:<LOCAL_PORT> R:<TARGET_PORT>:127.0.0.1:<TARGET_PORT> # Mutiple ports fowarding, can be different targets in the same subnet ./chisel client <LOCAL_IP>:<LOCAL_PORT> R:8080:172.17.0.2:8080 R:5000:172.17.0.3:5000 Socks5 # In our local Linux machine sudo nano /etc/proxychains4.conf # Add to the end of the file socks5 127.0.0.1 1081 # In target machine .

item.title: Nmap
item.description: Nmap Scan TCP UDP Script target=<TARGET> nmap -p- --min-rate 10000 -oA ./nmap-alltcp $target ports=$(cat nmap-alltcp.nmap| grep -Eo "^[0-9]+" | tr '\n' ',' | sed -r 's/,$//') nmap -p $ports -sCV -oA ./nmap-tcpscripts $target target=<TARGET> nmap -sU --min-rate 10000 -oA ./nmap-udp $target ports=$(cat nmap-udp.nmap| grep -Eo "^[0-9]+" | tr '\n' ',' | sed -r 's/,$//') nmap -p $ports -sU -sCV -oA ./nmap-udpscripts $target Update scripts DB nmap --script-updatedb Search scripts # e.

item.title: openvpn
item.description: Connect to vpn sudo openvpn my_vpn.ovpn

item.title: VPN
item.description: Enum # Check with ikeV1 ike-scan -M <TARGET> # Check with ikeV2 ike-scan -M --ikev2 <TARGET> Connect to VPN strongswan sudo apt install strongswan Settings # Edit /etc/ipsec.secrets %any : PSK <PASSWORD> # Edit /etc/ipsec.conf (copy from ike-scan result) config setup charondebug="all" uniqueids=yes strictcrlpolicy=no conn testvpn authby=secret auto=add ike=3des-sha1-modp1024! esp=3des-sha1! type=transport keyexchange=ikev1 left=<LOCAL> right=<TARGET> rightsubnet=<TARGET>[tcp] Connect # Reset ipsec restart # Connect ipsec up testvpn
